Posts.Content: Hi Rosielee Chemotherapy was what I dreaded the most, and although in shock when told got BC and felt rubbish after lumpectomy and lymph node removal - when I was told I had cancer in two of the lymph nodes and needed chemo, I melted down. Four weeks waiting for chemo didn't help, but i did sort of get my head around it. managed to speak to a couple of people who have recently been through  -found that really helped. Had my 2nd chemo last Friday, so Day 3 today. Not a walk in the park and we all react differently, but if you accept you won't be doing alot for the first week, recovering for the second week and then have a week feeling yourself again - I was told that by a colleague and mine pretty much followed that pattern. Honestly it's better when you're on the road - at least you're knocking them down  -I am now a third of the way through 3xFEC and 3x Tax. Next one will be halfway! We all have down times - have a good cry, let it out, and then do whatever you need to get through. Good luck and hugs Clare xx
Posts.Title: Feeling as though the cancer is now real

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca Even though it was only March/April, I look back on that limbo time and it it is a blur. I was not sleeping, trying to finish things off at work as well as dealing with the enormity of diagnosis. I felt like i was barely able to function, it was awful. It is definitely the worst time of my 3 month experience so far. Being on the chemo road is not nice, but mentally it is a smooth ride in my opinion! Hope today goes well Clare x
Posts.Title: Surprised by effect of stress.

Posts.Content: Well I went for my 3rd and final FEC on Friday afternoon. Had felt a bit extra tired the previous evening and Friday morning, and had to wait for ages to go in and felt fairly rough but still up for it. Cold cap went on, and felt a bit sick and dizzy as I do when it first goes on but usually passes after a minute or two. This feeling did not pass, and when the nurse came back 20 mins later I was nearly passing out. BP and all other obs were ok, but felt awful. So didn't have chemo, said they would re-book for Monday, but can't do it til Friday 20th. Really hacked off. Disappointed in myself and frustrated at not getting it done. Stupid as no obvious illness. Still feel extra tired and headache-y. Dr said it may be due to an accumulation of the drug and a late reaction - after only 2 chemo sessions - great! Just to make me feel even more inadequate, there was a lovely 75yr old lady next to me on her last session, who had barely felt the effects! And there's me at 49 throwing a wobbler and failing to even have my 3rd FEC! Worried now that if I don't feel better on Friday, the cold cap might be too much to bear and I have to go without it. Although my hair is now so-oooo thin, I don't know if it worth bothering.... Miserable weekend, its changed all my summer plans by a week, won't even be able to take my to son to his orthodontist appt next week. Sorry to rant, first time I've started a thread. Roll on Friday and get FEC done and dusted. Clare
Posts.Title: Friday 13th FEC'ed me off!!

Posts.Content: Thanks ladies Well I now realise that I have the virus that my son had the week before, so at least I have a proper reason, and didn't just throw a wobbler! I don't do patient either but now trying to rest loads and get fit for Friday. Managed to get son in to a cancellation at orthodontist today, so got one thing done..  Rebecca - pity you're not Friday too. Have to collect meds on Thursday - are you am or pm? I'll look out for you! Dorothee - hope you're recovered after that FEC, bet you're looking forward to more........ Clare
Posts.Title: Friday 13th FEC'ed me off!!

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne Pleased you're feeling positive about your wig. I have used cold cap, and have avoided a wig for 3 months as started chemo 31st May. But the dreaded Tax has thinned it more drastically, with my scalp now showing, and the last dose (Yay!!) I have had today  will thin it further. I bought a wig at the outset (wierd paying alot of money for something I was hoping not to need!!) and had it trimmed and fitted again last Monday. Wore it to go out on Tuesday night and all day yesterday, and it felt strange but good. I bumped into a friend of a friend in Debenhams and she said  "oh you've had your hair cut" - asked her if she thought it looked ok and she said "yes really good" - she couldn't believe it was a wig when I told her! made me feel better! I also feel better about mine because it really does make me look healthier than my very thin hair, and when I put make up on which it sort of makes me do, as I dont wear alot normally, it's even better! Good luck!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne Pleased you're feeling positive about your wig. I have used cold cap, and have avoided a wig for 3 months as started chemo 31st May. But the dreaded Tax has thinned it more drastically, with my scalp now showing, and the last dose (Yay!!) I have had today  will thin it further. I bought a wig at the outset (wierd paying alot of money for something I was hoping not to need!!) and had it trimmed and fitted again last Monday. Wore it to go out on Tuesday night and all day yesterday, and it felt strange but good. I bumped into a friend of a friend in Debenhams and she said  "oh you've had your hair cut" - asked her if she thought it looked ok and she said "yes really good" - she couldn't believe it was a wig when I told her! made me feel better! I also feel better about mine because it really does make me look healthier than my very thin hair, and when I put make up on which it sort of makes me do, as I dont wear alot normally, it's even better! Good luck!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi to all I have not had rads yet, but a friend has experienced the uncovering and laying there whilst undergoing treatment. Not looking forward to this as I have worked closely with quite a few of the therapeutic radiographers, male and female!! Planning to ask about covering up, what arrangements are made and make sure some are in place for all patients, not just special treatment for me!! To all - DO NOT PUT UP WITH THIS. You have an absolute right for privacy and dignity. If there is no arrangement for minimal exposure of the breast - ask why not. My breast care clinic has small capes with velcro front fastening, similar to trisha, sounds like all should have this and things won't change unless we KICK UP A FUSS - for ourselves and future patients. Also am having photos done for a trial, and know the medical photographer very well - think he may be more embarrasssed than me!! Don't mind the tattoo, although hate them. Not as bad as a scar! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Is RADS always like this?

Posts.Content: Hi Jelly and Rebecca Hope the Tax isn't affecting you too badly so far. As you know, my first one was awful. This one has definitely been better already. The pains started Sunday evening and I had 3 rough days (including an overnight in hosp Tues due to temp up, but only 24hrs) but started feeling better Wed pm and managed to be off the painkillers from yesterday. Pat is so-oooooooo right about the emotional side - I got upset and frustrated a few times on FEC, but have been an emotional wreck at times with this. Be prepared - warn other halves!! I sucked ice cubes during my Tax chemos and have had no mouth ulcers/sores/thrush. It is horribly cotton woolly and everything tastes foul, although this did ease in the last week of the cycle. Haven't found anything that tastes nice. No hot flushes for me on Tax - loads on FEC. Very very fatigued. Thought FEC had me tired. Had to lie down after my (short) shower this morning - even my heart was going like the clappers like I'd done 100m! Funny effect with steroids - didn't get me first tax, but was bounding around like Tigger this time! I hated the lower dose on FEC - made me feel shaky and funny, but taking a higher dose was very interesting! Let us know how you get on won't you Clare xx
Posts.Title: T Tips Please

Posts.Content: Hi Tinkers Scary info about nodes. I had lumpectomy and 4 nodes out in April. Cancer cells in 2 nodes, so am now on FEC-T route (2 out of 6 - grateful for all recent tax info). Thought the chemo was to kill those stray cells!! Scary to know it may not work! Will talk to my onc about this! Don't particularly relish node clearance and it effects, but would rather stay cancer free. Clare
Posts.Title: Just had my first chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Tinkers Scary info about nodes. I had lumpectomy and 4 nodes out in April. Cancer cells in 2 nodes, so am now on FEC-T route (2 out of 6 - grateful for all recent tax info). Thought the chemo was to kill those stray cells!! Scary to know it may not work! Will talk to my onc about this! Don't particularly relish node clearance and it effects, but would rather stay cancer free. Clare
Posts.Title: Just had my first chemo

Posts.Content: Great story Mary! I finished chemo today and got in the car after and just burst into tears on my hubby. He knows not to say anything, bless him,  he just cuddles me, and he too wiped a tear as we recovered. I have three teenage kids too and I am fully aware how much my diagnosis and treatment - particularly the chemo - has affected them all. I am a bit worried about how i will cope woth Tamoxifen next, but radiotherapy after should be a doddle, and I can think about going back to work (I think having me at home to nag more has got on the kids nerves too!). Once the next 7-10 days are over, then I will celebrate!! Hope all else goes well for you Clare xx
Posts.Title: A post chemo smile!

Posts.Content: Hi All I too try to drink lots and lots. Important to remember to drink before chemo and blood tests as well, as it helps our blood pressure and access to our veins - very helpful down the line when our veins start to hide! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Can you have to much water?

Posts.Content: Hi Caryn Good for you going commando!! My last chemo was 21st Sept, and I realised that my hair was starting to grow a couple of weeks ago. I used cold cap but have been wearing my wig since before last chemo as my hair was so thin you could see my scalp. Last Thursday I took the plunge and had all my wispy longer bits cut off and a no. 5 all over to even it up and trim off the baby hair. I am thrilled to bits with it, but haven't yet got the nerve to go commando!! Have set myself a target of wig-free by Christmas - should have a good amount by then at the rate it is growing. I was lucky and haven't lost all my eyebrows (got just enough to follow when using the eyebrow powder) or eyelashes (most of lower ones gone but upper not bad). Have just ordered the Eyelure falsies for the festive period after seeing recommendation on here - wouldn't normally use anything like that but as the advert says - we deserve it!!  Might just treat myself to the Benefit mascara too!!! Thanks!! And as for lady garden - haven't lost all that either - the bits that stayed were the bikini line bits - so had to shave them when went on holiday recently!! Bizarre!!  Am sure hair everywhere will start growing rampantly soon with the menopause effects of Tamoxifen - Movember will be easy next year!! It's great to be finally nearing end of treatment isn't it? I am on week 2 of rads. Having support and info from here has made a huge difference. Love to all Clare xx
Posts.Title: going Commando !!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey Just to add my best wishes and admiration for going through this all again. Hope you get a forward solution Clare xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer for a second time in opposite breast

Posts.Content: I had a week in hospital being pumped full of antibiotics after first Tax too! Think it's rather common! Had an overnight stay after 2nd tax too, as temp went up, but settled.  I was offered a week's delay after the first, but wanted to get on with it, which made the second Tax tough too, as hadn't really recovered from the first. The third was a doddle in comparison. The pains and stuff did get much easier each time, for me and I think for most of us. Tax is tough, but think what it is doing to those cancer cells!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Had a melt down! Thanks for listening to my sound off!

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca I am a week past my second treatment, used cold cap for both. Had my long, very thick hair cut into a bob, it is now extremely thin on top, can't style it, and it looks a mess. There is hair all over the bed, bathroom and whole house! Noticed you're in Lincoln, me too. The cold caps at Lincoln are the soft gel type, not the refrigerated machine that a lot of centres have. Not sure what type others used, or how efficient different ones are. Clare xx PS Loved your previous post about the scarves! Perhaps you could start a bald model trend!!
Posts.Title: If the cap fits...

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel Really glad you're enjoying the hols, and brilliant about the puppy! I love getting out with my dog when I'm able - cheers me up no end! Have a great holiday next week - hope the weather keeps up for you. We're off to Norfolk this weekend, not sure we'll manage anything longer, juggling between chemo, hubby's work, and A level and GCSE results week! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel Really glad you're enjoying the hols, and brilliant about the puppy! I love getting out with my dog when I'm able - cheers me up no end! Have a great holiday next week - hope the weather keeps up for you. We're off to Norfolk this weekend, not sure we'll manage anything longer, juggling between chemo, hubby's work, and A level and GCSE results week! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne So pleased for you great news, and no need to worry about axillary node clearance. Opinion and practice on ANC seems to vary across the country. I had 2 out of 4 nodes with cancer cells after an anatomical node sampling, so was offered chemo, but was not offered total ANC - and am very glad for it, as the sampling caused enough problems with pain and cording, but others on this site seem to have been advised to have ANC in my situation. So happy for your good results - this week has been magical! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Are there alternatives to total auxilliary node clearances?

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel Glad you managed to have a good holiday, bit of normality with the kids is wonderful isn't it. I've been in Norfolk with family one weekend, and mum and sister last weekend - my mum (82yrs and doesn't get out much) loved it! Hope your appt goes well tomorrow, remember to say on arrival that you must see the consultant - not that horrible reg from last time! Presume you have hubby with you, take your questions with you and get hubby to take notes. And don't let them rush you - this is your time and your body, take what you need from your consultation, ask again and again if not sure about something - all health professionals are used to repeating info to ensure understanding (or should be) and it is their responsibility to make sure you are clear about everything.  Hope chemo Thurs goes ok - it's your first Tax isn't it? Got mine on Friday - dreading it. Clare xx
Posts.Title: Terrified of ONC appt tomorrow :(

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel Glad you managed to have a good holiday, bit of normality with the kids is wonderful isn't it. I've been in Norfolk with family one weekend, and mum and sister last weekend - my mum (82yrs and doesn't get out much) loved it! Hope your appt goes well tomorrow, remember to say on arrival that you must see the consultant - not that horrible reg from last time! Presume you have hubby with you, take your questions with you and get hubby to take notes. And don't let them rush you - this is your time and your body, take what you need from your consultation, ask again and again if not sure about something - all health professionals are used to repeating info to ensure understanding (or should be) and it is their responsibility to make sure you are clear about everything.  Hope chemo Thurs goes ok - it's your first Tax isn't it? Got mine on Friday - dreading it. Clare xx
Posts.Title: Terrified of ONC appt tomorrow :(

Posts.Content: Hi Janice Thank you so much for such a positive post. I am 2/3rds through chemo and have just spent a week  as an in-patient in the hospital where I work, watching the nurses dashing around, my colleagues popping in to see me as they leave work late, and wondered how on earth I am going to drag myself back to those levels of energy - and whether I ever will. Your post is a real boost and a reminder that 'normality' is possible again! Long may it continue! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Living again

Posts.Content: Hi All A late response to this, but haven't been on for a while and am excited about my hair! I used the cold cap throughout (had my long hair cut to a bob) and my hair gradually got thinner and thinner, even still falling out week before last. I found a heavier loss with Tax too (had FEC_T), and I finally had to give up, and started wearing my wig just before my final Tax 7 weeks ago. Anyway, had noticed a little bit of new growth 2 weeks ago which acelerated quickly. So last Thursday, I had my wispy longer bits cut off completely and a number 5 all over, to take off the soft baby hair. It looks amazing and I am thrilled to bits! I keep rubbing my hands over it - it feels lovely!! Quite a bit of grey, as expected, although I am lucky at 49 and am not too grey. Seems to be straight as before and not curly, thank goodness, and growing as strongly as ever. So-oooo exciting!!!! I haven't quite got the nerve yet to go out without my wig or a hat. I keep thinking I should be brave and go for the new look, but the whole point to me of using the cold cap and wearing a wig was that I do NOT want to look like a cancer patient, so I will let it grow a little longer yet, and keep my head warm with my wig! So the day WILL come and boy will it be exciting, I was bouncing on Thursday, ever and since!!!!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: when does your hair come back

Posts.Content: Ooooh Rebecca Glad you're over the worst. It does make the next week more enjoyable! I too am making the most of my second half of chemo. Enjoy! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Hooray...and up she rises!

Posts.Content: Good for you. Decision made, path clearer, gut feel followed  - no wonder you feel calm. A bit of control back. Well done!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Chemo - decision made

Posts.Content: Hi Lady Muck I have used cold cap through 3x FEC and 3x T, my last Tax was last Friday. Had long thick hair, cut into shoulder length bob pre chemo, which fell out lots but still looked like hair throughout the FEC. Tax hammered it further and it is now very noticeably thin. As the whole point to me was to try to keep hair and not look like a cancer patient, I have now started wearing my wig to go out. I am very happy that I used the cold cap as I have saved myself three months of wearing a wig, and hopefully will be able to stop wearing it earlier when my hair starts to grow and covers the thin patches. If you use cold cap, you will not be able to style your hair, or wash it frequently as others have said. The discomfort is a personal thing, but I agree that first few minutes are the worst. There are different types too. You could contact your chemo unit and find out which type. The nurses in my chemo unit weren't very keen on using it, and I had to ask and push for every aspect of it - they said I didn't need to wet my hair (although it is very obviously important) and didn't have a written protocol except for the instructions from the manufacturer - which took 20 minutes to find and print off on the first morning when I asked for it. I think I am a rarity on my unit to persist with it until the end and keep some hair! Good luck with your decision. As long as you're doing the right thing for you that's all that matters. Clare xx
Posts.Title: A Cold cap - did it work for you?

Posts.Content: Oh ladies, I love you all! I do feel loads better about tomorrow, was wiped out for 7-10 days on FEC, so how bad can it be!?!?! Squeaky hiccups may amuse the family!! Got painkillers at the ready, cant take codeine (makes me wappy - well wappier than usual!!). have Tramadol from previous back problems - they make me a bit muzzy, but that's quite useful for pain!  Had my nails painted a groovy deep purple today, not quite a summer colour but hey (normally have short nails, but are quite long at the moment as I am a lady of leisure). Kittycat - I had my hair trimmed last week too, just a tidy up - who would have thought it. Realised something else today, am 10 weeks since my first chemo, but in 6 weeks I will be having my last tomorrow - woo-hoo!! Too all ladies facing chemo - it has gone faster than I ever thought it would!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal for me better than FEC

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Have just started a thread about hating tax - have just come out from a week in hospital with neutropenia - so don't moan about the injections - definitely the better option!! I got them routinely for FEC (days 5-9), but not for Tax unless required, so I shall have them for next one. For those that don't know, they are a synthetic form of G-CSF - granulocyte-colony stimulating factor, known as filgrastim, and they stimulate the production of white blood cells, particularly neutrophils. Kittycat - glad your second one wasn't as bad as the first. Karen - hope you're doing ok on your second tax too. Luvvie - no sickness at all for me on tax, so hopefully much better for you Pat - love your wig story!!! No mouth sores, but did suck ice cubes - was shivering during treatment as cold cap as well but figured it was only an hour or so to save days of discomfort - and it was warm outside and I soon warmed up! My hair has started falling out more too, on the verge of needing to wear my wig now - tried it last night in the house and had to take it off afetr a couple of hours as it drove me mad - how do you stand to wear it all day??!! No hot flushes with Tax, had loads with FEC particularly in first week, easing to week 3 each time. The fatigue on Tax was different for me too. Wiped out on FEC but bounced back quick after Day 7; much more pyhsically affected with Tax and still much weaker 2 weeks on. Hopefully better next time!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal for me better than FEC

Posts.Content: Thanks kittycat, I have first Tax on Friday and had worked myself into a state earlier, although have been out with hubby for a meal tonight and chilled loads. You have helped further. I know it can vary, but nice to know wiped out FEC feeling may not happen. Hope it keeps up positive! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal for me better than FEC

Posts.Content: Good one Dorothee! Rebecca, don't wear contact lenses, but my eyes have been gritty a few times, normal other days. Tricky one, you may have to suck it and see. Clare
Posts.Title: Contact Lenses

Posts.Content: Hi kittycat Sorry you're still feeling crappy, this Docetaxel is one hell of a thing isn't it? I am nearly two weeks past mine now and have been variable. Last week was the usual horribleness, although the pain was quite a lot less and I managed without painkillers. This week I have managed to get out with the dog for quite decent distances. Had visitors yesterday and went suddenly shattered at tea-time and zombied all evening. Am fully prepared to be up and down for the next few weeks - have been warned by the chemo nurses and a friend who has been through it not to expect too much for 6 weeks. Will be on Tamoxifen by then, so will have those s/e's, and starting rads -  no rest for the wicked!! Hope all goes well for your surgery tomorrow - presumably they will double check bloods as you're feeling grotty, but at least you will be clearing the Tax out of your system as you recover from the the surgery. You'll be a new woman when you come out the other side!! Sue - I can sympathise with your abandoned feeling, but rest assured that they are so happy with your treatment and progress that they don't need to see you for ages! Could you speak to your your BCN about it? Maybe make an appt with her inbetween if it helps? Love to all Clare xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal - how long until you feel better??!!

Posts.Content: Hey Karen - are you recovering from the Tax now? I started being rough Sun night, day 3, and had an awful day yesterday - stabbing pain in lower back and legs, head and neck, and surgery scars, as well as feeling weak and uncomfortable and about 110 yrs old - but not as washed out as on FEC. Also threw a crying wobbly at tea-time, which is not like me at all. Went on the Tramadol last night and have had the day in bed today, as each time I went downstairs I felt awful after just a few minutes. Also wanted to be fitter this evening as son's girlfriend's birthday and her family are away - we had takeaway pizza and birthday cake, in the balmy garden, and it was lovely. Two very different evenings! Had been trying to keep moving around and off the pills on Monday - but am much better for being on the pills and resting - sometimes it is right to just give in! Will be sensible the rest of the week. Mouth just cotton-woolly so far, sucked ice cubes during infusion after tips on here (was shivering by the time I'd done, with cold cap as well - thankfully it was sunny and I soon warmed up outside!) Good luck to kittycat and Sue for your next dose this week - think I've read the Tax reaction gets a bit better each time? Fingers crossed! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal for me better than FEC

Posts.Content: Hi Jo Don't want to be negative, but I was hopeful of re-growth on Tax and it thinned even more. I have persevered with the cold cap, and it has now stopped shedding nearly 3 weeks after last tax. I can get away with a hat with hair sticking out underneath but have started wearing my wig without a hat as it is so very  thin. Don't regret using cold cap though as have got away without a wig for 3 months and have some hair, hopefully a good starting point for re-growth, although it will look very weird if it grows back curly with wispy straight bits!! Interestingly, my eyebrows and eyelashes didn't start to go until Tax, and still have some left, althouygh having to in-fill the eyebrows. Best of luck with your decision Clare xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had hair regrowth between cycles Fec and T?

Posts.Content: Oh, Tinkers - CONGRATULATIONS and thanks for sharing your good news. And to Ruthy and all others recently finished the main treatment. Glad you're all upbeat and determined to enjoy life - that's how I plan to be when this is done! It's such an inspiration to the rest of us to feel that the end will eventually come! Clare
Posts.Title: Finished my treatment today!

Posts.Content: Hi Louise Just to add support for your immeasurably tough situation. Are you happy with your team? Think in your situation, you could ask for secoind opinion - have you got a good GP you could talk it through with, or your BCN? Don't sit at home and worry with questions - write them down and get your answers Take care Clare xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: don't know what the hell to think anymore : (

Posts.Content: Oh Annie Sooooooooooooo happy for you to be finally getting proper consultation, proper info and that you are feeling so much more postive about your treatment. You have to insist on seeing this one Onc only. If I were you I would write to the Chief Executive or the Medical Director with comments about your positive and negative treatment. You should then get a full explanation of why you were given such varying info, and you can reasonably insist on seeing the main man from now. If you write it from the point of view of what a horrible frightening effect it has had on you they should take it very seriously, and please do not think it will count against you because it should have them jumping through hoops to treat you better. There will be a complaints policy on the website of the hospital. That woman reg needs to know what she does to people - was she a locum, I wonder? You would be helping yourself and others. Keep that chin up high, you lovely lady. You ARE stronger than your invader!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: never thought would be so happy to have surgery!!

Posts.Content: Hi Karen Not heard of Nioxin sorry. My scalp has been itching like fury and all flaky, with my half inch of growth and I have been wondering what to use. I am having radiotherapy and am using aqueous cream, which I know you can use for washing so wondered if I could use it on my scalp. I then looked on Trevor Sorbie's 'my new hair' site, which recommended just that. So the last 2 mornings, I have rubbed aqueous cream in to my hair/scalp (feels weird and cold!!!) before my shower (left it half an hour this morning) and just rinsed it out in the shower. Already my scalp is considerably less itchy and my hair feels great too!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Hair advice pls

Posts.Content: Hi Jane I am on Day 6 after second FEC, and yes every day different for me too. Get up thinking I feel ok, then need to sit down and rest, then surprise myself by able to do washing up or something. I too have muzzy head, headache on and off at this stage (happened last time at this point), but not lightheaded - are you drinking plenty? Keep drinking and drinking - it washes the nasty out of our system! If  worried, ring your chemo unit, they have presumably told you that. You are not bothering them - it is their job. Trust me, I work in NHS and would rather patients ring and ask than worry at home. Hope you feel better soon, but don't expect too much of yourself yet. I did not start to recover until Day 9 last round, but then picked up very quickly. Keep a record as well - you can feedback to your oncologist and hopefully get improvement next time (e.g. more anti-sickness, etc) Clare xx
Posts.Title: Day 6 after 1st FEC Chemo - still feel lightheaded

Posts.Content: Hi Annie I remember you being new in this job - so pleased how brilliant they have been and how excited you are about going back. I too have my last chemo next week, got rads to come but am thinking about when I can go back to work, might start clearing emails when I'm in for rads, as I work at the same hopsital. Isn't it wonderful to start thinking about normal life again!!!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Might be going back to work :)

Posts.Content: Hi Annie I remember you being new in this job - so pleased how brilliant they have been and how excited you are about going back. I too have my last chemo next week, got rads to come but am thinking about when I can go back to work, might start clearing emails when I'm in for rads, as I work at the same hopsital. Isn't it wonderful to start thinking about normal life again!!!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Might be going back to work :)

Posts.Content: I don't intend to become a BC survivor, I intend to just go back to my life as it was - ordinary, busy, not filled with hospital appts, not feeling like crap due to the treatment, not thinking about breast cancer. I have a 70yr old neighbour who is a pillar of the community - always busy, helping others, never stops. I found out when I told her my diagnosis that she had BC 20 yrs ago, never thinks about it now. She is my role model. Clare xx
Posts.Title: When do you graduate to being a BC SURVIVOR and stop being a patient...

Posts.Content: Hi Annie Congratulations on your last chemo!!!!! And so pleased that you saw the good onc! You make sure you see him every time - insist on it!! I finish chemo tomorrow, and Sarah you have put exactly into words how I am feeling - we have been concentrating on getting through that cycle of illness and recovery, now  the wider picture looms - next stages, going back to work, more treatment - rads and Tamoxifen for me - it's strange and exciting and scary at the same time. Annie, I hope you're on here with good news about your next stage soon Clare xx
Posts.Title: Onc appointment today, reality kicking in :(

Posts.Content: Kittycat - Congratulations!!!! What a fantastic post. Your happiness is so infectious and your words so brilliant. I have my last chemo tomorrow and can't believe its here - the last 4 months have dragged and gone quickly at the same time - am sure all you ladies will know what I mean! Someone posted to do something special 3 weeks after the last chemo, instead of having another one - think that's a great idea and am planning to do exactly that.  Enjoy your chemo free time - I am sure we will all never forget. Clare xx PS How's your hair - is it still ok with the cold cap and the dye?
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha I too sometimes wonder if my determination to try and minimise it means that I am not dealing with it properly, but I have other health problems (although don't sound as bad as yours!) and I don't let them rule my life either - as i'm sure you don't. Hope the wildfires I've just been watching on the BBC aren't affecting you. Looks awful. No such problem here, wettest summer in 100 years here! Clare xx
Posts.Title: When do you graduate to being a BC SURVIVOR and stop being a patient...

Posts.Content: Congratulations!!! It's a great feeling isn't ? Clare xx
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Oh kittycat, I think we are going to have to be patient............. A friend who went through this told me she recovered from her 2nd tax after 2 weeks, but her 3rd one took 6 weeks! I too am not too bad with this one either - shattered and no energy as before (funny how it's a different shatteredness to FEC) but not much pain, only stabs and aches I can cope with, so managing to keep off painkillers. Can't wait to get my guts back to normal. Sassy, glad FEC not too bad, I can identify with 'obeying the chemo god' - then enjoying sticking two fingers up at it when you get back out and about for the rest of the cycle. Can't wait to erase the shadow of the chemo god (well perhaps devil more apt??!!) from my life completely!!! Hope last FEC goes ok and that Tax treats you reasonably Clare xx
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Kittycat Day 4 of last Tax, and so far not so bad as the other two - fingers crossed! My hair is very thin now - you may have seen on other posts have started wearing my wig to go out - it makes me look so much healthier! Am hoping not to need wig for too long, as hoping hair will fill in when starts to grow - my only worry is if it starts to grow back curly as they say it can - that would look good - curly short growth with straight wispy shoulder length bob! I could start a new trend!!! So yours is growing back and still coming out?  Hope it soon gets on an even keel. Having it cut shorter sounds like a good idea.  Hope you're feeling great! Clare PS Clareybear is a hubby endearment - guess I should have a bear as my piccy, but love birdwatching and the bird is one of my favourites - a Sanderling, regularly seen on the beach in gorgeous North Norfolk.
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Tracie Crikey, no wonder you feel paranoid you poor love. I can see that it must be really  hard to see a way forward right now, each of those things would send anyone reeling. Have you talked to someone? It sounds like some support would be really useful and help you to move forward. You have done so well to keep going - sounds like you're really doing your Mum proud. Love and hugs Clare xx
Posts.Title: Feeling paranoid, dare I think of a future

Posts.Content: Been away for a few days, so not been on online. Sascha, just to add to the message that i hope you have now got - you are brave, brilliant, fun, helpful, and in the right place - do not go anywhere. If i have learnt anything from this forum is that we are all so different - in our condition and treatment. BUT we all have the same thing in common, not only that we have bc but that we are women who are here to ask for and give help and support to each other, whatever our exact situation. Clare xx
Posts.Title: Not sure if I still belong here or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel I too am finding that once the main affects of the chemo have started to fade, about Day 10 for me, I get my appetite back with a vengeance! Can't do big meals, but tending to eat small and (very) often. Craving carbs - has to be a sandwich or cereals. Eating salad is torture - can't do it on its own, so tending to have a sandwich and salad as compromise. Not put weight on though, so just listening to my body and letting it eat what it needs. Not interested in wine until the third week, so letting myself have the odd glass then - sounds like we'll go right off it when we have T anyway! Think we are entitled to eat what we need to get through as well as what we feel is healthy  - a reasonable compromise! Clare xx
Posts.Title: eating like a big fat pig!

Posts.Content: Babs, so pleased for your wonderful news - celebrate!! Jellytot - good for you too! What a great news week this week has been!! Love to all still waiting for results Clare xx
Posts.Title: best onc app ever

Posts.Content: Hi mary I'm an inbetween reaction: 4 weeks post FEC-T my nails are on the yellow side and very fragile, but haven't lost any. Have had 3 nails fracture in the last week - and they weren't very long! They are now filed extremely short and shall keep them that way until they look healthy. Had forgotten about the oncolife stuff - will get some - thanks flissbee. My nails didn't hurt though - hope yours are ok Clarexx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel / Finger nails

Posts.Content: Hi beevergirl Thanks for sharing your name origin with us - love it! My maiden name was Windsor and was often called windy miller at school - now there would have been an appropriate nickname, with regard to the side effects of chemo!!!!!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Naïve or a dingbat

Posts.Content: Hi Rusty Welcome to the ups and downs of breast cancer. I was diagnosed March (age 49,healthy too) and it seems like only yesterday but a million years ago at the the same time! I felt like I was living in an alternate reality, but it has become the norm now, halfway through chemo. This site is brilliant for info and support, ask any questions you like and there will be someone pointing the way! I didn't find it when very first diagnosed, wish i had. Good luck with the surgery. Give yourself time to recover. Do the stretches that they will give you, they really help. Great that you have a wonderful holiday to enjoy. Clare
Posts.Title: New to all this!!

Posts.Content: Hi Rusty Glad you've had a lovely day and escaped for a bit - a big boost on such a lovely day. I have often thought how lucky I am to be going through this in spring/summer - well and autumn actually! To cope with it in the long dark winter would surely be harder. Yes, I was upset to no longer give blood. I had to cancel an appt when first diagnosed and he said he thought I may not be able to give blood again, then I got a 'final' certificate in the post a few days later! (Followed by a further appt the next day amusingly - one dept not speaking to another, I guess - typical NHS!!) Good idea to throw your efforts into fundraising - a friend of mine is organising a fashion show locally,  for breastcancercare - alot of hard work. Been looking at the Macmillan coffee morning on 28th Sept, but am due last chemo 1 week before, so don't know if i dare as if get delayed, it could be on that day. Would be good as 4 days prior is 21 yrs since my dad died of cancer and macmillan nurses were amazing. Clare xx
Posts.Title: New to all this!!

Posts.Content: Hi Jo Yep, me too! My arm started hurting at end of first cycle, and the second lot of FEC really hurt going in, until they put a warm wheat bag on which really helped. No advice what to do about it until I saw onc just before my third and when I asked him, he told me to stretch and stretch it, with weights in my hand if need be. I couldn't even hold my handbag in that arm at the time. My 3rd FEC then got delayed for a week due to a virus, during which I stretched for England and it hurt like hell but was tons easier just after a week and alot less painful 3rd infusion. Thankfully I only had 3 FEC, and Tax did not make them any worse, don't know how you'll go on with 6 FEC, bless you. You would think they would offer you a line with having 6. It really annoys me that the vein damage was never mentioned to me as a side effect, nor is it in the Macmillan FEC info! When I had blood taken recently the lovely plebotomist told me that it would take years to heal, if ever from the sympathetic look on her face. Mine are like piano wires in my arm but I stretch regularly and reach with it as much as possible and it doesn't hurt - just looks ugly and imposssible to bleed!  Haven't found anything to rub on, although I did wonder about arnica. I would definitely ask about a line - you may have to be pushy!!! Good luck Clare xx
Posts.Title: collapsing veins in chemo arm!

Posts.Content: Hi Jo Yep, me too! My arm started hurting at end of first cycle, and the second lot of FEC really hurt going in, until they put a warm wheat bag on which really helped. No advice what to do about it until I saw onc just before my third and when I asked him, he told me to stretch and stretch it, with weights in my hand if need be. I couldn't even hold my handbag in that arm at the time. My 3rd FEC then got delayed for a week due to a virus, during which I stretched for England and it hurt like hell but was tons easier just after a week and alot less painful 3rd infusion. Thankfully I only had 3 FEC, and Tax did not make them any worse, don't know how you'll go on with 6 FEC, bless you. You would think they would offer you a line with having 6. It really annoys me that the vein damage was never mentioned to me as a side effect, nor is it in the Macmillan FEC info! When I had blood taken recently the lovely plebotomist told me that it would take years to heal, if ever from the sympathetic look on her face. Mine are like piano wires in my arm but I stretch regularly and reach with it as much as possible and it doesn't hurt - just looks ugly and imposssible to bleed!  Haven't found anything to rub on, although I did wonder about arnica. I would definitely ask about a line - you may have to be pushy!!! Good luck Clare xx
Posts.Title: collapsing veins in chemo arm!

Posts.Content: Hi jellytot This is brilliant - an amazing description. 2 weeks post my last tax, I took my son to hospital for a tooth out under GA yesterday, collapsed exhausted into bed when got home in the afternoon and slept for 2 hours, then slept like a log last night too. I feel very lucky that I will recover from this, but this is how some people have to live their lives permanently. Thanks Clare xx
Posts.Title: The Spoon Theory

Posts.Content: Hi Patricia So glad you are over the worst, and feel human again. Fingers crossed that it wont happen again - others have said the first is the worst. Have had mine today, and am prepared........... Clare xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Pat Glad you're starting to get over the Tax. Have my first Tax this Friday and dreading it. All good info though - I would rather be prepared for the worst - and if it's not so bad it's a bonus. Have Tramadol already from previous trapped nerve in back ,and am seeing GP on Wednesday to prepare for everything else! Thanks for sharing. I have noticed from other posts that the first tax is usually the worst, so fingers crossed for you! Clare
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Hi jellytot I had the bone pain on my first Tax and hadn't been given the injections - so yes they are separate. (Have them now after going neutropenic after first one) Also on the first one, I had the walking round like a 100 year old woman, but not quite as bad (perhaps 70 year old??!!) the second time. First time I had diarrhoea, second time days of constipation followed by days of horrific reflex diarrhoea - lost over half a stone since been on tax! So variable! So i do agree with others that it gets better (less bad!!) each time. Am hoping so for my last one next week! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Love it! Thanks for the giggle! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Made me smile.....

Posts.Content: I think I got mine from Amazon, although there is also a Chillow website. Used it last night, swapping it in for my usual pillow when I woke up roasting hot at 3.00am (it's always around 3am!!). It was lovely and cooling but I was then very restless for the next hour and a half, not sure whether I was not quite comfy enough with the pillow in which I have put the Chillow, or just restless! By 4.30am it did not feel very cool to my head any more, but I wasn't roasting hot at all the rest of the night. It does have such a different feel than my usual pillow, I think that is my I struggle with it. I always have been fussy about my pillow!! Let me know if you get one!! Have fun!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Chillow - any good ?

Posts.Content: Hi Patricia I have a Chillow, just an original one (£27.50).  I find it does cool me down beautifully, but is not very comfy - it is obviously a more solid surface than your usual pillow. I have it on a spare pillow and so can substitute it for my usual pillow in the night. Used it alot on FEC as lots of hot flushes and it was summer. Now having night sweats with Tamoxifen, but have a silk pillowcase as used cold cap and find that alone quite cooling and tend to stick with switching that around just because it is comfier, but am still having some hot, restless nights. I keep thinking I must put my Chillow on another pillow and try it again - but keep forgetting until I have a night sweat - in fact I'm going to do it right now...............watch this space! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Chillow - any good ?

Posts.Content: Dear Pioneer I want to thank you for bringing these sources of information to our attention. It is so difficult to find reliable sources of info. This is such a hugely emotive subject amongst this community - none of us want to think that the gruelling treatment we are enduring is a waste of time - we have to focus on the benefits. I, for one, am grateful to you and others for working towards a best solution to this issue. Information is so often the key to so many things!! Clare
Posts.Title: screening mammography

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca It was good to see you too. Sounds like you can aim for a joint visit for H and T - hope they do that at our centre. Think Dr C has that sort of nature - my hubby isn't keen on him. Think he doesn't waste words. I have found he does answer my questions, but sometimes have to push. Difficult though if you were caught out with your news, hard to then think on your feet!  Might be worth talking to BCN again, or ask for another appt. with Dr C. He does have a good reputation, found out more about him during my in-patient stay. Hope all goes well next week. Feeling ok after tax yesterday, although steroids had me bouncing off the ceiling last night - felt like the Duracell bunny!! Haven't slept much!! Off to Norfolk again today - hubby got some jobs to do there and I can sit and watch him!! Though might be on a cleaning frenzy if steroid effect doesn't ease off!! Clare xx
Posts.Title: FEC not working so moving on to T. Anyone else had this?

Posts.Content: Hi Highland Mum Good luck for your treatment. It was almost as big a shock as my diagnosis when I was told I had cancer cells in my lymph nodes and needed chemo. However here I am about to have my last one tomorrow. It's not fun, but it does pass. I have tamoxifen and radiotherapy next, but this stage will soon be over and the next one begun. Get all the chemo tips off the threads here, and there's lots of others just starting to share experiences with - it aint half useful to share! Wishing you all the best Clare xx
Posts.Title: Just told I need chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi jellytot I too started with this 2 weeks after my first FEC. Like Tina, I just thought I'd pulled something. My second session was agony when the Epirubicin went in. Saw the onc just before my third and he told me to stretch - hurts like hell, but makes a HUGE difference. Had a warm wheat bag on my arm for the 3rd FEC and it was much easier. 2 weeks after 3rd FEC, veins are tightening up again and I keep stretching. I can see and feel the veins all the way up my arm, and can't quite fully straighten it yet - but I will! I understand Tax isn't as bad on the veins, so sympathy to all having/had 6xFEC. Just another side effect we weren't warned about!!  Clare xx
Posts.Title: Sore arm/vein pain

Posts.Content: Oh beevergirl how wonderful! You must feel so blessed with such lovely friends and family. Glad you had such a wonderful time, hope the hangover passed quickly! Clare xx
Posts.Title: Count our blessings

Posts.Content: Dearest Annabel "She said there were lots of treatments for me" - that statement says a hell of a lot. She is not giving up on you, she is just badly organised and not very good at communicating!! You know as we all do that this is not a straight and predictable path. If you really want to know all your options, write to her (or even better, her boss - that'll make them sit up) and say that you want a consultation to discuss your prognosis and options. However, she may not be able to give you a clear outcome at this stage, things will probably be clearer when you have finished your chemo. You are so fortunate to be responding well to the chemo, focus on that for now and accept that more answers may take time in coming Lots of love Clare xx
Posts.Title: horrible onc appt, horrible news

Posts.Content: Hi Annie Hope your queasiness is dissipating. Managed to get my last FEC done yesterday, after my week delay. Taking it very steady this morning and ok so far - feels great to reach reach the halfway point and be done with FEC, but a little trepidadtion about Tax! You can insist that you see your consultant Onc, make sure you never see that useless registrar again. Are you being seen again before your next dose? If so, ring and make sure the Cons onc is there- he may not have been present at the clinic, and they may have thought it ok to be seen by a reg for a review - which you clearly aren't! When you get to the clinic make it clear that you will only see the Consultant - they will probably tell you that you might wait longer, but it sounds worth it. Or if i were you, and you can face another consultation, contact your onc secretary and tell her the trauma you have had and ask for an urgent appt - they should help. Working in the NHS, I do know that if you kick up a fuss (nicely helps, but be stroppy if you have to) it definitely helps when the wheels are not tuning as they should. Your onc may well be annoyed himself. If still not happy, definitely get a second opinion. Clare xx
Posts.Title: horrible onc appt, horrible news

Posts.Content: Hi All I am also having trouble with my veins on my good arm after only 2x FEC. Started with a dull ache in my inner elbow  2 weeks after first chemo, very painful going in second round and ached badly since, and started to tighten up like cording. Onc told me last week to stretch the veins, just like I had to with bad cording. Have been stretching and they are a little better, but very painful to stretch and not looking forward to next chemo. Onc said nothing i can apply topically to help, but am wondering about arnica or suchlike. No warning about this - am p'ed off as i thought i would keep one good side, and it's my dominant hand! More and more things to add to the fun! Clare
Posts.Title: Sore good arm

Posts.Content: Hi Ali and all Couldn't agree more with getting on with life and stuff worrying about cancer. I am now  weeks past chemo and discussed getting away at half term before rads with my oncologist - he told me to go abroad if i want !!! Said if i can't get travel insurance, just go in EU and take EHIC card. So, I have today booked us a week in Portugal in 6 days time!!!!! can't wait!!!! Hubby and teenagers need a break as much as i do!! Incidentally, American Express have covered me for my BC and my asthma for £96 for the year (rest of family total is £70) - thought that wasn't bad, as thought no-one would touch me as mid-treatment. Also wondering where to go for 50th birthday next year - it will be a couple of weeks after my 1 year diagnosis anniversary, so got to plan something special! Get that holiday booked and get on with normal life!!! Clare
Posts.Title: Tempting fate....ridiculous

Posts.Content: Hi Helen Interesting! i had 4 lymph nodes removed too, and they said they would not use the arm! Different centres! Yes, she slowed it last time, in the end I just told her to get on with it! Warm wheat bag helped too - shall have it from start next time. Thanks Clare
Posts.Title: Sore good arm

Posts.Content: Thanks Helen Stretched it loads this morning and it feels tons better for it. Am almost glad of delay as it feels loads better this week than last. Asked last time (as Epiribicin was really painful going in) whether they would ever consider doing it on the other side, where I have had some lymph nodes removed, and they said only under exceptional circumstances. Clare xx
Posts.Title: Sore good arm

Posts.Content: Yep I am in the club too! Hot flushes started with FEC, freezing cold on Tax (despite summer - well ,what bit we had) and now on Tamoxifen, night sweats, just developing into hot flushes in day too. Deep joy!!! Night night all!!   Sleep Well!! .................................................Not!! Clare xx PS 3am is usually my waking time - will think of all ladies awake too!!
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and nights sweats anyone....

Posts.Content: Coming to this late, but Sascha Rose - don't let the down days get to you - you have been amazing company on this journey, with your knowledge, opinions, information, positive comments and problems - we are all in this together, all have up and down days and are all here for each other. I agree that we can ignore the posts we aren't interested in and read and/or respond to the ones we are interested in. Just looking at how many of your threads and comments have been responded to shows you how wanted you are Sascha!! Come on my love, don't let everything get on top of you and deny your friends. WE are your friends. WE understand each other, even though we are hundreds of miles away. Please stay - we need your input!! Clare xxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Wishing everyone well and goodbye

Posts.Content: Hi Pollycat Sorry for the useless late reply (been away,still catching up!) hope you have managed to get through these injections ok. I got them for my 3xFEC, but was told not unless required for T. Well after a week in hopsital with neutropenia afetr 1st T, I now have them after my second T which was yesterday. Have been told to start them on Day 2 as well, it was Day 5-9 previously. I had some bone/joint pain with them last time but not too bad. Although given a toss up beteween the pain and the neutropenia - pain ain't as likely to kill ya!!  I am not mega Keen on doing mine - actually my hubby is gentler than me, but just remember to pinch the skin and stick it in there - I forgot to pinch on my last lot and it really hurt, then remembered and it was a doddle! Clare xx
Posts.Title: neupogen/filgastrim shots
